div1.p: Carter discusses his trip and the lack of field work at the moment.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Eugenia Hook Carter, June 7, 1915
div1.opener:
J.B. STANLEY CO., LUTA, WASH., D.C.
PHONE No 23
THE
NATIONAL HOTEL
J. D. MILLS,
OWNER & PROP.
SPECIAL LIVERY AND TRANSFER
ACCOMMODATIONS
RATES: $ 250 & 300 PER DAY
WADESBORO, N.C. June 7 1915 (night)
My Own Dear Child
div1.p:
I g did not get a chance to write
in the train yesterday. It was too jostly-
-“too much of a sea on” as LePrince
expressed it. We go If I had writ-
ten I am sure no one could have
read it.

We got in at one-thirty this mor-
ning & got up at 5 - or just before &
have been out all day. Can't say
that I am unduly tired, but judge
I will be able to sleep tonight
I am unquestionably stronger
than I thought I was.

Tell Laura that I found her letter
with enclosures here. They were given
me

PHONE No 23

me as my arrival but I did not
read them until in the boat about
2 P.M. today.

I am not going out tomorrow. In-
deed I think I will not have any
more field-work to do, until I get
back to Care the Coosa.- And only
2 or 2 1/2 days there.

Gorgas is here & was with us to-
day. I ju

I judge that Aileen & Mr Wright-
son - came north the same day
I did - saturday-sunday to monday-
div1.closer:
Your affectionate husband H. R. Carter How was
Sarah Champe?
